item.title: Hong Kong: US passes sanctions as nations condemn new law
item.description: The US House Speaker said the law was a "brutal, sweeping crackdown" against Hong Kong's people.

item.title: Coronavirus: 'I'm all for masks,' says Trump in change of tone
item.description: The president shifts course after his fellow Republicans urge Americans to wear face coverings.

item.title: Russia reforms: Putin strongly backed by voters, partial results
item.description: Victory would allow the president to stay in power until 2036, but critics say he wants to be a tsar.

item.title: Hagia Sophia: Turkey to rule on turning site into mosque
item.description: Turkey's Council of State rules on Thursday whether the iconic site can be turned back into a mosque.

item.title: Why Texas is seeing a surge in coronavirus cases
item.description: In the last week, the state has seen upwards of 6,000 new cases every day and hospitals are reaching capacity.

item.title: Hundreds of elephants found dead in Botswana
item.description: Some 350 elephant carcasses have been spotted in Botswana's Okavango Delta since May.

item.title: CIA did not verbally brief Trump on Russia report, says official
item.description: Mr Trump wasn't briefed on Russian allegations due to unverified information, a CIA official says.

item.title: Xinjiang: US seizes 'forced labour' Chinese hair imports
item.description: The products came from Xinjiang - where a million Muslims have been detained for "re-education".

item.title: US targets Monet and Warhol artworks in 1MDB case
item.description: The assets are allegedly linked to more than $4.5bn stolen from the Malaysian state investment fund.

item.title: New Zealand health minister resigns after blunders
item.description: David Clark had been under fire for breaking lockdown rules and for his response to the pandemic.

item.title: Haile Selassie: Statue of former Ethiopian leader destroyed in London park
item.description: Police are investigating the incident, which is being linked to unrest in Ethiopia.

item.title: Geoffrey Rush: Sydney newspaper loses appeal over defamation payout
item.description: Actor Geoffrey Rush will receive a record sum from an Australian newspaper, after it lost an appeal.

item.title: Judge gives go-ahead to tell-all book by Trump's niece
item.description: A New York court ruled the book's publisher can release the president's niece's family memoir.

item.title: My sexuality is not a sickness
item.description: Thirty years since the WHO said homosexuality was not a disorder, "gay conversion therapy" is still available.

item.title: Coronavirus: Six months that changed our world
item.description: A look back at how Covid-19 has swept the globe and altered the world in the course of six months.

item.title: Met Gala challenge paper dress goes viral
item.description: Fashion student Karina Bondareva recreated the dress worn by Cardi B at last year's Met Gala in New York.

item.title: Child with unicorn picture takes over TV interview
item.description: Dr Clare Wenham explained local lockdowns to viewers, despite her daughter's best efforts to distract her.

item.title: Tony Hudgell raises £1m walking 10km on prosthetic legs
item.description: Five-year-old Tony Hudgell set a target of raising £500 for the hospital that saved his life.

item.title: Coronavirus: Colombian mayor shops son to police for breaking lockdown
item.description: The town mayor in Colombia said he had to set an example after his son attended a party.

item.title: Photos of Portland's 'Avenue of Roses' win award
item.description: Life before and during lockdown is captured by 39 winning photographers.

item.title: Trump 'most informed person on planet earth' on US threats
item.description: The US president is under pressure over reports that Russia paid militants to kill American troops.

item.title: Hong Kong security law: Residents react to controversial new powers
item.description: Pro-democracy supporters say the move does not represent most Hong Kong people.

item.title: Hong Kong's new security law: Why it scares people
item.description: New crimes with severe penalties - what the security law brought in by China means in practice.

item.title: Wanchalearm Satsaksit: The Thai satirist abducted in broad daylight
item.description: Thai activist Wanchalearm Satsaksit has become the latest exiled Thai government critic to be abducted.

item.title: Trump, Russia and the Taliban: The story in 300 words
item.description: It's a complicated story about bounties and back channels. Let's break it down.

item.title: Ukraine floods: Why climate change and logging are blamed
item.description: Three hundred towns and villages were hit by flooding, and climate change and logging are blamed.

item.title: The fashion labels whose clothes are made by prisoners
item.description: A number of clothing firms are now getting their garments made behind bars.

item.title: Hachalu Hundessa - Ethiopia's murdered musician who sang for freedom
item.description: Hachalu Hundessa is due to be buried later on Thursday after 50 died in unrest following his murder.

item.title: Coronavirus: Could 'immunity passports' create an antibody elite?
item.description: Could Covid-19 antibody testing have the unintended consequence of creating an antibody elite?

item.title: Ms Marvel: Trailblazing Muslim superhero goes gaming
item.description: Marvel's first Islamic superhero will play a leading role in the forthcoming Avengers video game.

item.title: Yarmolenko hits late West Ham winner to stun Chelsea
item.description: Andriy Yarmolenko came off the bench to hit an injury-time winner to boost West Ham's survival bid against Chelsea at London stadium.

item.title: Arsenal boss Arteta 'very positive' about Aubameyang signing new deal
item.description: Mikel Arteta says he is "very positive" captain Pierre-Emerick Aubameyang will sign a new contract with Arsenal.

item.title: Everton 2-1 Leicester: Hosts boost European hopes with victory
item.description: Everton maintain their post-lockdown push for a place in next season's Europa League with an impressive home win over Leicester.

item.title: Thursday's football gossip: Arsenal and Inter linked to Griezmann
item.description: Arsenal and Inter Milan linked to Griezmann, Gunners step up Partey chase, Salah wants to stay at Liverpool for "long time", plus more.

item.title: Young and Sanchez score as Inter put six past Brescia
item.description: Ashley Young, Alexis Sanchez and Christian Eriksen all score and assist goals as Inter Milan thrash Brescia.

item.title: Bournemouth 1-4 Newcastle: Cherries fighting for survival after thrashing
item.description: Bournemouth's Premier League survival hopes are dealt another blow as Newcastle beat them comprehensively with an exciting performance at Vitality Stadium.

item.title: Batsman, coach, commentator, bridge player, knight - Weekes' glittering life
item.description: Sir Everton Weekes was the last of the famous 'Three Ws' of the West Indies side, and the only man to score five successive Test centuries.

item.title: 'The love letter to my neighbourhood that helped me flee my country'
item.description: José Gregorio Márquez was ashamed of the place he grew up, but he came to love it before leaving it forever.
